metadata.case_name: Rabia Bai v. Custodian-General of Evacuee Property

facts.text: Appellant Rabia Bai, Indian citizen residing at Grange, Yercaud, Salem District, desired to acquire immovable property.
Premises No. 20, Godown Street, G.T., Madras, belonged to Mohamad Gani Jan Mohamad who left for Pakistan in 1947 and settled there.
Mohamad Gani Jan Mohamad executed power of attorney in favour of nephew Ahmed Abdul Gani.
Ahmed Abdul Gani came to Madras in April 1949 and arranged sale; written agreement with appellant's husband on April 29, 1949, for Rs. 2,40,000; Rs. 1,50,000 paid immediately in cash and bank drafts.

Sale deed engrossed and sent to Karachi for execution by vendor; received back, stamped at Collector's Office on June 27, 1949; registered on August 11, 1949 after income-tax clearance; balance Rs. 30,000 paid to Mr. M. H. Ganni holding power of attorney.
Ordinance No. XII of 1949 promulgated June 13, 1949, extended to Madras on August 23, 1949.
Appellant applied for confirmation of sale on December 19, 1949.
Ordinance No. XII of 1949 repealed by Ordinance No. XXVII of 1949 on October 18, 1949.
Ordinance No. XXVII of 1949 repealed by Administration of Evacuee Property Act, XXXI of 1950 on April 17, 1950.
Assistant Custodian declared vendor's property evacuee property on January 11, 1951 under s.7(1), as vendor fell within s.2(d)(ii).
Assistant Custodian rejected confirmation on July 31, 1951 under s.40(4)(c) due to feverish hurry.

Custodian on appeal found valuable consideration but no good faith, rejected under s.40(4)(a) and (c) on February 4, 1953; relied on vendor leaving in June 1947, letter to Mohideen on July 4, 1949 expressing fear of new rules.
Custodian-General dismissed revision on July 4, 1954 under s.40(4)(a), finding no good faith due to haste and intent to evade laws.

legal_issues.text: Whether the sale transaction was entered into in good faith under s.40(4)(a) of the Administration of Evacuee Property Act, 1950, given the vendor's intent to evade apprehended evacuee laws.
Interpretation of 'good faith' in s.40(4)(a) - whether per General Clauses Act s.3(22) or context of evacuee laws.

petitioner_arguments.text: No evacuee law applied to Madras at time of negotiations and completion; evacuees free to deal with property.
Good faith per s.3(22) General Clauses Act: done honestly, even if negligent; no dishonesty in avoiding future law.
Government policy to confirm transfers to Indian nationals subject to income-tax and dues clearance.
Appellant paid valuable consideration and acted in good faith.

respondent_arguments.text: Vendor acted without good faith: left India June 1947, haste in sale, letter July 4, 1949 showing intent to dispose quickly to evade impending laws.
respondent_arguments.legal_basis: Administration of Evacuee Property Act, s.40(4)(a)

respondent_arguments.text: Good faith required of both vendor and vendee; vendor's conduct shows evasion.
respondent_arguments.legal_basis: Administration of Evacuee Property Act, s.40(4)(a)

court_reasoning.text: Good faith in s.40(4)(a) not strictly per General Clauses Act s.3(22); must consider context, object of Act to preserve evacuee property for inter-government adjustment.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Definitions in General Clauses Act apply unless repugnant to context.

court_reasoning.text: Transfers after Aug 14, 1947 hit by s.40(1); valid only if confirmed under s.40(4); deliberate intent to evade anticipated laws not good faith.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Vendor's letter shows knowledge of impending laws; intention to defeat Act not honest.

court_reasoning.text: s.40(4)(a) more stringent than T.P. Act s.53; protects even good faith purchaser if vendor lacks good faith.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Appellant's good faith irrelevant if vendor lacked it.

court_reasoning.text: Press notes/circulars subject to statutory provisions; no automatic confirmation.

holdings.text: Expression 'good faith' in s.40(4)(a) construed in context of Act's object; deliberate intention to defeat apprehended evacuee law not good faith.
Rejection of confirmation under s.40(4)(a) proper; transaction inoperative.

statutes_cited.name: Administration of Evacuee Property Act, 1950
statutes_cited.relevance: Governs confirmation of transfers by evacuees; rejection if not in good faith or for valuable consideration.

statutes_cited.name: Ordinance No. XII of 1949
statutes_cited.relevance: Imposed restrictions on evacuee transfers; extended to Madras Aug 23, 1949.

statutes_cited.name: Ordinance No. XXVII of 1949
statutes_cited.relevance: Repealed prior Ordinance; transfers after Aug 14, 1947 ineffective without confirmation.

statutes_cited.name: General Clauses Act, 1897
statutes_cited.relevance: Definition of good faith applicable unless repugnant to context.

statutes_cited.name: Transfer of Property Act
statutes_cited.relevance: Contrasted; less stringent than s.40(4)(a) as protects good faith transferee.

outcome.summary: Appeal by special leave dismissed; order of Custodian-General rejecting confirmation of sale under s.40(4)(a) upheld as transaction not entered into in good faith by vendor intending to evade evacuee laws.

key_quotes.text: "a deliberate intention to defeat the apprehended application of the evacuee law which was responsible for the transfer in question brings the transfer within the mischief of s. 40(4)(a)".
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Core holding on interpretation of good faith.

key_quotes.text: "the expression good faith used in s. 40(4)(a) has been properly construed by the respondent".
key_quotes.speaker: court

key_quotes.text: "if the matter is delayed there would be many sort of new difficulties as you know that the Government are passing new rules every day".
key_quotes.speaker: vendor
key_quotes.significance: Evidence of vendor's intent to evade laws.
